Award.AwardTitle: FW-HTF-P: Investigating Acceptability in the Workforce of Collaborative Robots that Provide and Request Assistance on an As-Needed Basis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this project is to investigate the social acceptability of collaborative robotic assistants, as-needed, amongst human workers in manufacturing and warehousing to address fear of workplace robots. The project investigates the perception of robotic assistants that attempt to preserve independence, recognition of worker contribution, and emotional well-being, while ensuring safety. This is done by contributing artificial intelligence (AI) that enables robots to intervene for assistance in simultaneous physical interactions such as object lifting only when necessary, i.e., on an as-needed basis. The work has the potential to revitalize manufacturing in rural North America, where fear of robots taking over human jobs is prevalent. The research team will be extensively involved in developing connections with the St. Lawrence County Industrial Development Agency, targeted toward supporting small businesses in the North Country Area. Through these connections, the research team will collaborate with local workers and managers to understand perceptions of robotics in the workplace. They will also provide demonstrations of proposed AI technology that provides assistance only when necessary, in order to preserve worker independence and job security while ensuring safety. The project will involve researchers at the confluence of robotics, organizational psychology, and physical therapy, and provide multi-disciplinary research and curricular opportunities to students from 2-year and 4-year colleges with limited technological opportunities in the North Country region.<br/><br/>As part of this planning grant, two objectives will be accomplished. First, the researchers will engage in strengthening collaborations in the area of socially acceptable robotics by forging partnerships with companies contributing and using work-place AI, and by organizing a workshop on large-scale concerns for socially acceptable workplace robotics. Second, a novel prototype AI system will be created that automatically predicts need for assistance from multi-viewpoint, multi-modal sensor captures of subjects participating in attempts to lift cartons of varying sizes, masses, and mass distributions. The research team will conduct studies on the effectiveness of the AI system in predicting assistance need by recruiting human participants from the workforce. The planning phase will advance knowledge in future technology and future workers through the contribution of the intelligent need for assistance algorithms, and the assessment of social acceptability of assistance predictors for workplace robotics. Discussions through the workshop are expected to contribute novel lines of thought on multiple fronts: (a) design of AI algorithms for workplace robots that are mindful of large-scale concerns such as assurance of emotional well-being and job-security of large employee groups across several levels; (b) balancing perceptions of safety versus independence from viewpoints of multiple stakeholders, e.g., workers, managers, business owners, and end-users; (c) effect of demographic, geographic, and socioeconomic factors; and (d) long-term economic impact of varying levels of robot autonomy. The ultimate goal of this project is to develop the necessary research personnel, research infrastructure, and foundational work to expand the opportunities for studying future technology, future workers, and future work at the level of a FW-HTF full research proposal.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project funded through the FW-HTF-P planning phase grant has laid the foundation for investigating the social acceptability of collaborative as-needed robotic assistants amongst human workers in manufacturing and warehousing to address fear of workplace robots. The project particularly targeted providing assistive solutions to workers engaged in physically-demanding tasks, such as lifting. Workers in industrial environments often report physical injury from lifting. Lifting-related injuries adversely impact female workers, and older adults, the latter being an important concern in the light of the aging workforce especially in rural regions. Though robotic solutions have the potential to provide assistance to workers, they also bring with them fears of robotic displacement. The project sets the stage to investigate the potential for human-robot collaboration (HRC), where robots provide help only when needed, to improve worker outlook toward robots, by for instance preserving worker independence.

Through a survey of 530 workers across 4 countries and 6 blue-collar job domains, the project drew conclusions on the potential for collaborative robots that provide and request assistance as-needed to be positively viewed in terms of preserving safety and independence, especially amongst women and older adults. The grant funds also enabled the project team to conduct pilot studies on using artificial intelligence (AI) and multi-modal sensing to detect object weight and effort invested in performing lifting attempts with identical packages of different weights, with and without the user knowing the weight beforehand. Multimodal data, particularly high-speed color, depth, and thermal videos of lifting activity were captured for 24 subjects in the PI's multi-camera lab. Sensing of weight and effort was performed from body skeleton points based on time taken to conduct lift, and from thermal imprint data left behind after lift. The pilot studies have laid the ground on using AI to detect if a person needs help to inform robots on being aware of worker needs.

During the planning phase, the grant enabled the PI to forge and strengthen connections with stakeholders in warehousing in rural North Country New York, biomechanical research company Delsys, and a business development agency supporting small and medium scale industries in North Country. The grant also helped the PI bring together academic and industrial experts spanning AI, robotics, multimodal sensing, physical therapy, sociology, ethics, and economics facilitating a holistic investigation of introducing collaborative robotics into the workforce. Through the connections built, the team are now pursuing a full-scale research grant geared at building collaborative robots that use AI to develop awareness of worker needs, with studies planned with stakeholders to understand worker attitudes toward need-aware collaborative robots. The connections forged through this grant form a vital link to help rural small businesses in industries such as warehousing, manufacturing, and transportation introduce novel technology while being workforce aware and ensuring that technology costs do not cause rural businesses to lose competitive edge to large companies.

The grant has enabled multiple U.S. citizen students from rural upstate New York pursue graduate degrees, and has supported the research of one female non-traditional U.S. citizen student to pursue her PhD. One alumnus is now a full-time employee at Delsys, a partner on this project. The PI presented results of the work at the Quotidien Machine Ethics workshop organized by Galois, discussing the need to develop industrial HRC that builds worker-robot trust and protects against job displacement.
